markdownRemark.html:
• Multiplicative Chernoff bounds let us reason about the deviation of a random variable from its expectation, much like Markov's inequality.

[!info] Markov's Inequality

For a nonnegative random variable $X$ and $v > 0$, $$ \text{Pr}[X \geq v] \leq \frac{\mathbb{E}[X]}{v} $$

To establish the bound, first let $X = X_{1} + \dots + X_{n}$, where $X_{i}$ is an independent indicator random variable with $\mathbb{E}[X_{i}] = p_{i}$ and $\mu = \mathbb{E}[X] = \sum_{i} p_{i}$.

[!success] Upper-tail Multiplicative Chernoff Bound

$$ \text{Pr}[X \geq (1 + \delta)\mu] \leq \left(\frac{e^\delta}{(1 + \delta)^{1 + \delta}} \right)^\mu $$

for some $\delta > 0$.

[!success] Lower-tail Multiplicative Chernoff Bound

$$ \text{Pr}[X \leq (1 - \delta)\mu] \leq \left(\frac{e^{-\delta}}{(1 - \delta)^{1 - \delta}} \right)^\mu $$

for some $\delta$ where $0 < \delta < 1$.

Proof of Upper-tail Multiplicative Chernoff Bound

  • Uses the Chernoff bounding technique - reasoning about $e^{tX}$ instead of $X$, since small deviations in $X$ correspond to large deviations in $e^{tX}$
  • Notice that $X \geq (1 + \delta)\mu$ when $e^{tX} \geq e^{t(1 + \delta)\mu}$ for any $t \geq 0$.

So we have: $$ \text{Pr}[X \geq (1 + \delta)\mu] = \text{Pr}[e^{tX} \geq e^{t(1 + \delta)\mu}] $$ Applying Markov's inequality, we see that: $$ \text{Pr}[e^{tX} \geq e^{t(1 + \delta)\mu}] \leq \frac{\mathbb{E}[e^{tX}]}{e^{t(1 + \delta)\mu}} $$ We can then simplify the expression $\frac{\mathbb{E}[e^{tX}]}{e^{t(1 + \delta)\mu}}$ as follows: $$ \begin{align} \frac{\mathbb{E}[e^{tX}]}{e^{t(1 + \delta)\mu}} = \mathbb{E}[e^{tX}] * e^{-t(1 + \delta)\mu} \ = e^{-t(1 + \delta)\mu} * \mathbb{E}[e^{t(X_{1} + \dots + X_{n})}] \ = e^{-t(1 + \delta)\mu} * \mathbb{E}\left[\prod_{i} e^{tX_{i}} \right] \end{align} $$

  • Observe that for independent random variables $Y$ and $Z$, $\mathbb{E}[YZ] = \mathbb{E}[Y] * \mathbb{E}[Z]$.

Use the above fact to get: $$ e^{-t(1 + \delta)\mu} * \mathbb{E}\left[\prod_{i}e^{tX_{i}} \right] = e^{-t(1 + \delta)\mu} * \prod_{i} \mathbb{E}[e^{tX_{i}}] $$

  • Recall that $\text{Pr}[X_{i} = 1] = p_{i}$ and $\text{Pr}[X_{i} = 0] = 1 - p_{i}$. When $X_{i} = 1$, $e^{tX_{i}} = e^t$, and when $X_{i} = 0$, $e^{tX_{i}} = 1$.

Use the above fact to see that: $$ \begin{align} \mathbb{E}[e^{tX_{i}}] = \text{Pr}[e^{tX_{i}} = e^t] * e^t + \text{Pr}[e^{tX_{i}} = 1] * 1 \ = e^{t}p_{i} + 1 - p_{i} \ = 1 + p_{i}(e^t - 1) \end{align} $$ Returning to our application of Markov's inequality, we see that: $$ \text{Pr}[e^{tX} \geq e^{t(1 + \delta)\mu}] \leq e^{-t(1 + \delta)u} * \prod_{i} \left(1 + p_{i}(e^t - 1)\right) $$

  • Observe that for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $1 + x \leq e^x$.

Use the above fact to get: $$ 1 + p_{i}(e^t - 1) \leq e^{p_{i}(e^t - 1)} $$ Applying this to our previously computed upper bound, we see that: $$ e^{-t(1 + \delta)\mu} * \prod_{i} \left(1 + p_{i}(e^t - 1) \right) \leq e^{-t(1 + \delta)\mu} * \prod_{i} e^{p_{i}(e^t - 1)} $$ $e^{-t(1 + \delta)\mu} * \prod_{i} e^{p_{i}(e^t - 1)}$ can be further simplified as follows: $$ \begin{align} e^{-t(1 + \delta)\mu} * \prod_{i} e^{p_{i}(e^t - 1)} = e^{-t(1 + \delta)\mu} * e^{(e^t - 1)\sum_{i} p_{i}} \ = e^{-t(1 + \delta)\mu} * e^{(e^t - 1)\mu} \ = e^{\mu(e^t - 1 -t(1 + \delta))} \end{align} $$

  • To find a tight bound, we want to minimize the value of $f(t) = e^t - 1 - t(1 + \delta)$ - start by taking the derivative and setting it to $0$ to find an extremum, then take the second derivative and see if it is positive (which confirms that the extremum is a minimum as opposed to a maximum)

$$ \begin{align} f'(t) = e^t - (1 + \delta) = 0 \ e^t = 1 + \delta \ t = \ln(1 + \delta) \end{align} $$ Computing the second derivative, we see that: $$ \begin{align} f''(t) = e^t \ = e^{\ln(1 + \delta)} \ = 1 + \delta > 0 \ \end{align} $$

  • $t$ that minimizes the Multiplicative Chernoff bound is $1 + \delta$

Substitute $t = 1 + \delta$ into our previously computed bound expression to get: $$ \begin{align} e^{\mu(e^t - 1 - t(1 + \delta))} \geq e^{\mu(e^{\ln(1 + \delta)} - 1 - \ln(1 + \delta)(1 + \delta))} \ = e^{\mu((1 + \delta) - 1 - \ln(1 + \delta)(1 + \delta))} \ = e^{\mu(\delta - \ln(1 + \delta)(1 + \delta))} \ = (e^{\delta - \ln(1 + \delta)(1 + \delta)})^\mu \ = \left(\frac{e^\delta}{e^{\ln(1 + \delta)(1 + \delta)}}\right)^\mu \ = \left(\frac{e^\delta}{(e^{\ln(1 + \delta)})^{1 + \delta}} \right)^\mu \ = \left(\frac{e^\delta}{(1 + \delta)^{1 + \delta}} \right)^\mu \end{align} $$ In the end, we can now conclude that: $$ \text{Pr}[X \geq (1 + \delta)\mu] = \text{Pr}[e^{tX} \geq e^{t(1 + \delta)\mu}] \leq \left(\frac{e^\delta}{(1 + \delta)^{1 + \delta}} \right)^\mu $$
